fields: {{c1::Protonated::protonated/unprotonated}} form of a weak acid is the more liposoluble form
{{c1::Unprotonated::protonated/unprotonated}} form of a weak base is the more liposoluble form
{{c1::P-glycoprotein (MDR1)::What cellular organelle}} <u>reduces drug absorption</u> by pumping absorbed drug back out into the lumen
Primary active transport; line the gut
Acidic drugs bind to {{c1::plasma albumin::which plasma proteins}} which can affect drug distribution
<u>Basic (pH) drugs</u> bind to {{c1::α1-acid glycoprotein::which plasma proteins}} and can affect drug distribution
Drugs can <u>accumulate in tissues</u> and serve as a {{c1::reservoir}} that prolongs drug action
Drugs that can enter the blood-brain barrier must be highly {{c1::liposoluble}} or {{c2::have an active transporter}}

What effect describes when a fraction of a drug is metabolized in the gut wall and liver before reaching the blood?

{{c1::First-pass effect}}

Adverse Drug Reaction
Type {{c1::D}} are delayed ADR's that are very rare and most commonly associated with cancer chemotherapeutic agents
Exaggeration of desired pharmacologic action of a drug are examples of {{c1::On-target}} adverse effects
i.e. Hypoglycemia caused by insulin, bleeding caused by anticoagulants
Activation of an incorrect receptor are examples of {{c1::off-target}} adverse effects
i.e. Enatiomers of a drug, or drug targeting histamine receptors but also have a high affinity for a potassium channels
If {{c2::Gingko biloba}} (herb) is used with NSAID there is an increased risk of {{c1::bleeding}}

because it also inhibits platelet aggregation
Week 2 DLA 3 - Adverse Drug Reactions

increased risk of bleeding if used simultaneously with NSAIDs
Week 2 DLA 3 - Adverse Drug Reactions
St. John's Wort has {{c1::antidepressant}} effects and can inrease risk of serotonergic syndrome

if taken with SSRIs simultaneously
Week 2 DLA 3 - Adverse Drug Reactions
<u>Phase 1</u> reactions of drug metabolism usually occur in the {{c1::ER}} of the cell
<u>Phase 2</u> reactions of drug metabolism are usually in the {{c1::cytosol}}
{{c1::CYP3A4}} isoform of CYP450 metabolizes ~50% of all drugs
accounts for 30% of CYP450 in liver
{{c1::Grapefruit juice::What fruit?}} can inhibit both CYP3A4 and P-glycoprotein in the small intestine

Which drug undergos Phase II reactions before Phase I?

{{c1::Isoniazid}}
Adhesive molecules connect cells together in the ECM (i.e. {{c1::laminin}} and {{c1::fibronectin}})
Component of ECM
To find Loading Dose (LD) when intermittent doses are given, the target concentration should be the {{c1::peak concentration at steady state (PCss)}}

What is an alternative formula to find the loading dose (LD) with intermittent dosing using accumulation factor (AF)?

{{c1::}}
i.e. a drug is given once every half-life: AF = 2 -> loading dose is 2x the maintenance dose

What happens to the drug's half-life if the dose is doubled?

{{c1::Prolong drug effect by one half-life}}
Double drug dose -> double drug plasma concentration

Which stain is used to identify special iron deposits (hemosiderin)?

{{c1::Prussian blue}}
since it produce a golden-brown on H&E stain which can be mistaken for lipofucsin

Can tophi (urate crystals) accumulation from gout be identified with XR's?

{{c1::No}}
Patients who have physicians who are good communicators are {{c1::more}} satisfied, and {{c1::less}} likely to file a malpractice suit {{c1::::More or Less}}
Saying sorry is not a demonstration of empathy

Demonstration of Empathy can be aided by the NURS mneumonic:

N{{c1::ame}}
U{{c2::nderstand}}
R{{c3::espect}}
S{{c4::upport}}

Do drugs have an ability to add functions?

{{c1::No}}
{{c1::Pharmacodynamics::Term}}: the study of effects of drugs and their mechanisms of action.
{{c1::Pharmacokinetics::Term}}: the study of absorption, distribution, metabolism and excretion of drugs.

Which drug below has the greatest potency?
{{c1::Drug E}}

Which drug below has the greatest efficacy?
{{c1::Drug D}}
Ketamine, a dissociative anesthetic, is a {{c1::noncompetitive}} antagonist at the NMDA receptor.
A drug is considered to be selective when a {{c1::10}} fold difference between its first target and its second target
In order for a drug to be useful as a therapeutic tool it must act {{c1::selectively}} on particular types of receptors.
ie, it must show a <u>high degree of binding selectivity. </u>
The term {{c1::refractoriness}} is also sometimes used to describe tolerance, mainly in relation to a loss of therapeutic efficacy.

Enlarged lymph nodes due to an infection is term what?

{{c1::Lymphadenitis}}

What term describes inflammation of the lymphatic channels that occurs as a result of infection at a site distal to the channel?

{{c1::Lymphangitis}}
Oxygen independent microbe killing results in a {{c1::decrease}} in pH due to build up of {{c2::lactic}} acid
Recall that without oxygen, normally, lactic acid will increase ➞ ↓ pH.
Any factor that {{c1::accelerates}} gastric emptying will be likely to {{c2::increase}} the rate of drug absorption
Any factor that delays gastric emptying is expected to have the opposite effect, regardless of the characteristics of the drug.

Which organ is better is favored to absorb an oral drug based on blood flow?

{{c1::Intestines}}
Blood flow to the intestine is much greater than the flow to the stomach, thus absorption from the intestine is favored over that from the stomach.
A drug that acts as a substrate for P-Glycoprotein will have a {{c1::reduced}} bioavailibility
A {{c1::sinus}} is a connection between a cavity lined with granulation tissue
A {{c1::fistula}} is a connection between two epithelial line surfaces
Fracture repair can be complicated by infection and result in {{c1::mal}}-union which is characterized by angulation of healing
If infusion rate is {{c2::doubled}}, steady-state plasma concentration is {{c1::doubled}}
The {{c1::Accumulation Factor (AF)}} predicts the ratio of the peak concentration at steady state to the peak concentration after the first dose

Does the uterus undergo hyperplasia or hypertrophy during pregnancy?

{{c1::Both :)}}

Select the correct items in the correct locations.
An enlarged spleen with white areas of amyloid deposits is termed a {{c1::sago}} spleen
Pulmonary anthracosis is intially caused by carbon accumulating within {{c1::macrophages::cell type}}

What substance accumulates in alveolar macrophages to cause pulmonary anthracosis?

{{c1::Carbon}}

How does pulmonary anthracosis generally present?

{{c1::It doesn't :)}}

This is because its asymptomatic. 
It can however become symptomatic if the carbon dust inhaled is mixed with silica (Then called silicosis)

What population(s) is likely at risk for developing pulmonary antharcosis?

{{c1::Smokers, Coal miners, Urban Dwellers}}

Dystrophic calcification during fat necrosis of the pancreas
will present with {{c1::hypo}}-calcemia

What accounts for the major differences in drug metabolism from individual to individual?

{{c1::Single Nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs)}}

Any two people differ on average at about one nucleotide in every 1,000 in their genome, totaling an average interindividual difference of 3 million base pairs throughout the genome. 

The majority of these differences are so-called single nucleotide polymorphisms or SNPs, in which one nucleotide is exchanged for another at a given position. 

SNPs and other differences in DNA sequence can occur anywhere in the genome, in both coding regions and noncoding regions.
One effect of genetic variation on pharmacotherapy is {{c1::metabolism/transport}} in which a drug has a different clearance

What is the genetic composition of a slow acetylator for isoniazid?

{{c1::Homozygous recessive}}
Some ultrarapid metabolizers can have up to 13 copies of the gene.
Individuals with multiple copies of the CYP2D6 gene will need a {{c1::lower}} dose if given codeine.

Codeine is ineffective in poor metabolizers because it requires CYP2D6-catalyzed conversion to morphine. 

Ultrarapid metabolizers may require very high doses of drugs that are metabolized by CYP2D6. But they can overdose with codeine, suffering respiratory depression or even respiratory arrest in response to standard doses.
Individuals with thiopurine S-methyltransferase polymorphism will require a {{c1::lower}} dose of 6-mercaptopurine
Must be treated with approximately 1/10th of the standard dose

TPMT catalyzes the S-methylation of the anticancer thiopurines 6-mercaptopurine and azathioprine. Methylation of these drugs inactivates them. 

Thiopurines have a narrow therapeutic window and some patients suffer from life-threatening myelosuppression.
Codeine will be {{c1::inneffective}} in an individual who is a poor metabolizer
Codeine is ineffective in poor metabolizers because it requires CYP2D6-catalyzed conversion to morphine
Gefitinib is an inhibitor of {{c1::EGFR tyrosine kinase}}
Gefitinib is used to treat {{c1::nonsmall cell}} lung cancer

Which form of warfarin is more potent?

{{c1::S-Warfarin::S- or R-}}

What gene is responsible for variation in S-warfarin metabolism?

{{c1::CYP2C9}}

What general tumor type describes growth that arises from embryonic tissue?

{{c1::Blastoma}}

What stain can be used to measure proliferation (rate of growth) in neoplastic cells?

{{c1::Ki67}}

• Metastasis is defined as a tumor implant discontinuous from the primary tumor.
• Metastasis is an unequivocal sign of malignancy.

What is the likely method in which sarcomas are spread?

{{c1::Hematogenous Spread}}

What location in the body is a common deposit for hematogenous spread of neoplasm?

{{c1::Liver}} and {{c1::Lungs}}
A malignant tumor is characterized by {{c1::poorly}} demarcated cells
